article.title: Planck Sunyaev-Zel'dovich Cluster Mass Calibration using Hyper Suprime-Cam Weak Lensing

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the color of the circles representing Planck clusters indicate?
choices: Cluster mass
Cluster richness
Cluster redshift
Observational depth

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the black outlines in Figure 1 represent?
choices: Observed HSC-SSP Wide fields
Planned HSC-SSP Wide fields
Fields observed by other surveys
Regions masked due to bright stars

multiple_choice_question.text: What is indicated by the green circle in each image?
choices: SZ peak of the cluster
Location of the central galaxy
X-ray peak of the cluster
Region used for weak lensing analysis

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be observed about the morphology of the Planck clusters shown in these images?
choices: They are all relaxed and spherical.
They often exhibit substructure and signs of mergers.
They are all dominated by a single, bright central galaxy.
They are all located in isolated environments.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main reason for the difference in the fitted mass between the P-cut and CC-cut profiles?
choices: Statistical noise in the weak lensing signal
Different assumptions in the NFW model fitting
Contamination from cluster members and foreground galaxies in the P-cut sample
Systematic errors in the HSC shape measurements

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does the comparison of the stacked lensing analysis (blue star) with other WL studies suggest about the mass bias (1-b)?
choices: It is consistent with unity, indicating no bias.
It decreases with increasing redshift.
It could be a function of cluster mass.
It is systematically lower than the Planck CMB value.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the parameter "b" in this formula represent?
choices: The shear bias in weak lensing measurements
The redshift of the cluster
The bias between the measured SZ mass and the true cluster mass
The concentration parameter of the NFW profile

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is an Eddington bias correction (CEB) applied to the Planck SZ masses in this formula?
choices: To account for the dilution of the lensing signal by foreground galaxies
To correct for the assumption of hydrostatic equilibrium in the X-ray mass estimates
To account for the scatter in the SZ-mass relation and the preferential selection of more massive clusters
To correct for the miscentering of clusters in the weak lensing analysis
